div.p: GArdening, and the plea≈øant Delights of a Curious Orchard, has been the Delight of many great Per≈øons, and Wi≈øe Men of all Ages; who have therein contemplated the Wonders of God in Nature, and refre≈øhed their Minds, as well as ≈øollaced their Bodies: There, by the help of Art, the Hand-maid to Nature, are produced ≈øuch Things as are highly worthy of Admiration, whil≈øt the travelling Sun labours to impregnate the Earth with a kindly Heat, and enables her to produce ≈øuch various kinds of Fruits, Herbs, Plants, Flowers, Shrubs, &c. of different Kinds, Ta≈øtes, Colours, Scents, Shapes, and Virtues; ravi≈øhing to the Eye, plea≈øing to the Ta≈øte and Smell, and nouri≈øhing to the Body, all which taking with admirable Delight, ≈øhould incite Men not only to covet them, but to Labour in moderate Exerci≈øe for improving and propagating them.

A Method, to do which, I have in this Book laid down, the better to invite the Ingenious and Indu≈øtrious, to what mu≈øt needs yield them a great mea≈øure of Plea≈øure and Profit, having laboured in every Thing to advance this Art, as near as may be to its highe≈øt Perfection, omitting nothing that can be grateful to my Countrymen, as to what relates to Fruit-trees in all their Particulars; ordering Fruit when ripe, and making curious Liquor, and Wines of them.

Having con≈øidered all Things for making a compleat Gardener, either to ≈øerve himfelf or others, and be grateful to Gentlemen and Ladies, who are curious in the≈øe Matters, worthy of all Per≈øons Care, of what Degree ≈øoever.

A good Orchard and Garden, by all prudent Phy≈øicians are held much to contribute to the Health, as well as Plea≈øure of tho≈øe that often frequent them in their refre≈øhing Walks and ∆≤mbrages.
